Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "When the $(DesignTimeBuild) flag changes, build.props is invalidated" (#1958) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build
2. Cause a Design-Time Build to occur
3. Build again
4. More things build than _should_

Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1933
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/pull/1943

One of the issues I noticed while debugging the issue with #1933 is
that `$(IntermediateOutputPath)build.props` gets invalidated if
`$(DesignTimeBuild)` changes. `build.props` triggers alot of targets
to build completely again, so this is pretty bad for our build times
in an IDE...

Design-Time Builds can run quite frequently in VS Windows, and we
don't want to rebuild a bunch of things unnecessarily when the user
switches back to a regular build.

### Expected Behavior

Design-time builds should not invalidate `obj\Debug\build.props`, and therefore:

Design-time builds should not trigger any of the following targets if there are _no changes_:
- `_LinkAssembliesNoShrink`
- `_UpdateAndroidResgen`

### Actual Behavior

Design-time builds cause a future build (even with no changes) to be slower.

### Version Information

Happens on master/d15-8.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] use designtimebuild.props" (#1957) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1933
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/pull/1943

One of the issues I noticed while debugging the issue with #1933 is
that `$(IntermediateOutputPath)build.props` gets invalidated if
`$(DesignTimeBuild)` changes. `build.props` triggers alot of targets
to build completely again, so this is pretty bad for our build times
in an IDE...

Design-Time Builds can run quite frequently in VS Windows, and we
don't want to rebuild a bunch of things unnecessarily when the user
switches back to a regular build.

So a solution, is to use a `designtimebuild.props` that works
independantly of `build.props`. This prevents some slower targets from
running when they shouldn't, such as `_UpdateAndroidResgen`.

I added a test to validate these changes, which also verify that
`IncrementalClean` isn't deleting these files.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Design-Time Resource.designer.cs can get out of date" (#1956) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Opened pull request "Add Linux Mint to the fold" (#1955) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Add detection and preparation script for the Linux Mint distribution. Since Mint
is based on Ubuntu, this patch reorganizes things a little bit to reuse as much
of Ubuntu specific code as possible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[timing] use Release build of xabuild/xamarin-android if possible" (#1940) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
When timing builds, and plotting them on Jenkins, we should prefer to
use the `Release` build output of `xamarin-android` if it exists.

This also will fix a problem downstream in `monodroid`, where I'm not
able to profile `Debug` builds because `bin\Debug` *might* not exist.
`monodroid` seems to mostly use `Release` builds of `xamarin-android`.
We really need to profile `Debug` Xamarin.Android application builds
so that we can see how `Fast Deployment` is performing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[tests] fix CheckTargetFrameworkVersion tests" (#1949) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/pull/1916

These tests were never quite right, since they were just looking for
instances of `TargetFrameworkVersion` in the build log. This would
match for inputs and outputs, and wasn't actually testing anything
because it appeared to always pass.

In #1916 I improved them by looking for
`Output Property: TargetFrameworkVersion=v2.3`, but they were
not passing.

Two issues to fix:
- These tests should set `AndroidUseLatestPlatformSdk=False`
- These tests shouldn't use `StringAssertEx.Contains` because it calls
  `Assert.Pass`, skipping any future assertions...

When testing on Windows, these tests get skipped, so I had to fix
things on Mac. The PR builder also skips them, so we did not see the
issue until it was merged into master.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Platform Specific -> Android Bottom Tabs Set Shift Mode" (#3289) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we can set bottom tabs on Android with the new stuff in Xamarin.Forms 3.1, but if you add more then 3 items then it will auto start shifting :(

The code to adjust this can be found: https://github.com/jamesmontemagno/Xamarin-Templates/blob/master/Xamarin.Android-Templates/Projects/BottomTabsApp/BlankAppCompat/BottomNavigationViewUtils.cs

This would be a nice addition please!

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[UWP] grouped listiview which can load more crashes if scroll too fast" (#2832) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
Here is a customize listview which load 30 more items each time, if I turn on isgroupingenabled, then the user can not scroll too fast. Everything works fine for non-grouped listivew.
I tried to change the number to load to a larger number, the issue still exists.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run the sample app
2. scroll rapidly vs scroll slowly
3. crash / work

### Expected Behavior
Everything should be fine
### Actual Behavior
scroll too fast crashes the app
### Basic Information
[BlankApp1.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2039445/BlankApp1.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NSAttributedString.Key values are not bound" (#4428) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new Workbook 
2. Add a `UILabel`: 
    var lbl = new UILabel(new CGRect(30, 30, 100, 100)); 
    RootViewController.View.AddSubview(lbl); 
   
3. Create an `NSMutableAttributedString` : 
    var text = new NSMutableAttributedString("Hello, World!");

4. Use the `AddAttribute(NSString, NSObject,NSRange)` method to set the first word to bold:

    text.AddAttribute(new NSString("NSFont"), UIFont.BoldSystemFontOfSize(17), new NSRange(0, 5));
    lbl.AttributedText = text;

### Expected Behavior

The first argument's value should be defined as an easy-to-find constant (e.g., `NSAttributedStringKey`) 

### Actual Behavior

I had to run `NSAttributedString.Key.font as NSString` in a Swift playground to discover the value.

### Environment
